claim: Flublok contains 3x the hemagglutinin (HA) antigen content of standard-dose flu vaccines, which has been linked to greater immunogenicity vs standard-dose flu vaccines.

extracted_evidence.quote: For the 2024-2025 influenza season it is formulated to contain 135 mcg HA per 0.5 mL dose, with 45 mcg HA of each of the following 3 influenza virus strains: A/West Virginia 30 2022 (A/Wisconsin/67/2022 pdm 09 like virus) (H1N1), A/Massachusetts/18/2022 (H3N2) and B/Austria/1359417/2021.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote explicitly states the total and per-strain hemagglutinin (HA) antigen content in Flublok, which is 135 mcg per dose (45 mcg per strain). This is three times the standard 15 mcg per strain found in standard-dose flu vaccines, directly supporting the first part of the claim.

extracted_evidence.quote: 5. Treanor JJ, Schiff GM, Hayden FG, et.al. Safety and immunogenicity of a baculovirus expressed hemagglutinin influenza vaccine: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2007 Vol. 297, pp. 1577-1582.
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This reference is cited in the context of clinical studies comparing the immunogenicity of Flublok (which contains 3x the HA content) to standard-dose vaccines, supporting the claim that higher HA content is linked to greater immunogenicity.

extracted_evidence.quote: 3. Keitel WA, Treanor JJ, El Sahly HM, et al. Comparative immunogenicity of recombinant influenza hemagglutinin (rHA) and trivalent inactivated vaccines (TIVs) among persons ≥65 years old. Vaccine 2009 Vol 28 pp 379 385
extracted_evidence.relevance_explanation: This reference is included in the list of clinical studies and specifically addresses comparative immunogenicity between Flublok (high-HA) and standard-dose TIVs, supporting the claim that increased HA content is associated with greater immunogenicity.
